This represents the three propositions as follows:

1. Blue and yellow are both common colors: p1&p2
2. Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational: ~p3||p4
3. Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational: [(p3 | p4) & (~p3 & ~p4)]

This is a level C formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one level B formula. The expression "(p3 | p4) & (~p3 & ~p4)" in the third proposition is a level B formula, as it contains one logical connective (the "&" operator) and its connected two propositions "(p3 | p4)" and "~p3 & ~p4" are both level A formulas.

[[A];[C]]

(1) For this formula, we can perform a truth table to check its truth value under all assignments. Since we are only given three propositions p1, p2, and p3, we will consider all possible combinations of true (✓) and false (x) for these propositions.

| p1 | p2 | p3 | p1||p2||p3 | p1=::>(p1||p2||p3) |
|---|---|---|--------|----------------------|
| ✓  | ✓  | ✓   |  ✓            |  ✓                 |
| ✓  | ✓  | x   |  ✓            |  ✓                 |
| ✓  | x  | ✓   |  ✓            |  ✓                 |
| ✓  | x  | x   |   x            |  F                  |
| x  | ✓  | ✓   |  ✓            |  ✓                 |
| x  | ✓  | x   |   x            |   F                 |
| x  | x  | ✓   |   x            |   F                 |
| x  | x  | x   |   x            |   T                 |

Since there is at least one false assignment for this formula, it is not a Truth Formula. However, it is also not a Falsehood Formula, since there is at least one true assignment. So, the answer is neither.

(2) For this formula, we will consider the following cases:

If p1 is true (✓) and p1 is equal to its negation (~p1), then p1=::>~p1 evaluates as false. If ~p2 is true (✓), then the overall formula evaluates as true due to the "if...then" rule (p1=::>~p2).

However, if p1 is false (x) and p1 is equal to its negation (~p1), then p1=::>~p1 evaluates as true. If ~p2 is false (x), then the overall formula evaluates as false due to the "if...then" rule (p1=::>~p2).

So, there are no false assignments for this formula, which means it is a Truth Formula.

[[B];[A]] Unlike my earlier response, I will use commas to separate the answers for each sub-question.

(1)~(p1=::>p2)&p2
- The negation of "p1 if p2" (~(p1=::>p2)) is true only when p1 is true and p2 is false. since p2 is in the scope of the negation, it negates p2 as well. As a result, the formula is true when p2 is false. So, this formula is false when p2 is true. This makes it a falsehood formula for the assignment where p2=true.

(2) (p1&p3)=(~p1&~p2)
- On either side of the equivalence operator, the two formulas have different structures. So, we have to check the conditions for each formula to be true or false.

- Taking the left side of the operatior, for (p1&p3) to be true, both p1 and p3 should be true.

- Taking the right side of the operator, for (~p1&~p2) to be true, both negated propositions (~p1 and ~p2) should be true. This means p1 and p2 should be false.

- Since the left side of the operator requires both p1 and p3 to be true, while the right side does not depend on p3, this formula will be false only when p1 is true and p2 is false.

In conclusion, (2) (p1&p3)=(~p1&~p2) is a falsehood formula for assignments of p1=true and p2=false.

[[C]] The formula (¬p∧¬q∧r)∨ (p∧q∧r) is a basic formula because it contains a single paired conjunctive term, which is m3 (corresponding to the true assignment of ¬p∧¬q∧r), as can be seen from the principal disjunctive normal form.
However, since there is only one paired conjunctive term in the principal disjunctive normal form, it does not include any even or odd paired conjunctive terms. Therefore, it is neither an all-even nor an all-odd formula.
So the answer should be: [[C]].

[[[A]] The paired disjunctive normal form for the given formula (¬p∧¬q∧¬r)V(¬p∧¬q∧r)V(¬p∧q∧r)V(p∧¬q∧r)V(p∧q∧r) is:
- (¬m1)V(m2)V(m3)V(m4)

Here, m1 represents the paired disjunctive term of ¬p∧¬q∧¬r, m2 represents the paired disjunctive term of ¬p∧¬q∧r, m3 represents the paired disjunctive term of ¬p∧q∧r, and m4 represents the paired disjunctive term of p∧q∧r.

[[[A]] The given formula (p∨r)∧(¬q∨r)∧(¬p∨q∨¬r) can be rewritten in conjunctive normal form (CNF) as follows: (p∨r) ∧ (¬q∨r) ∧ (¬p ∨ q ∨ ¬r) ≡ (p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) ∧ (p ∧ q ∧ ¬r) ∧ (¬p ∧ r).

There are 3 length-3 clauses in this CNF: {p, ¬q, r}, {p, q, ¬r}, and {¬p, r}.

In order for this CNF to be the principal CNF, each of these clauses must be one of the paired conjunctive terms (m_i). Let's verify that the conditions for a paired conjunctive term are met for these clauses:

1) Each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once in each clause.
- {p, ¬q, r}: p, ¬q, and r appear, and their negations do not appear.
- {p, q, ¬r}: p and q appear, and their negations do not appear.
- {¬p, r}: ¬p and r appear, and their negations do not appear.
2) The variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order in each clause.
- {p, ¬q, r}: The variables (p, ¬q, and r) in lexicographical order are p, ¬q, and r.
- {p, q, ¬r}: The variables (p, q, and ¬r) in lexicographical order are p, q, and ¬r.
- {¬p, r}: The variables (¬p and r) in lexicographical order are ¬p and r.

Since each clause meets the conditions for a paired conjunctive term, the given formula (p∨r)∧(¬q∨r)∧(¬p∨q∨¬r) can be represented as the principal CNF of the formula. Its denoted expression is [(m_i), (m_j), (m_k)], where i, j, and k correspond to the indices of the paired conjunctive terms (m_i, m_j, and m_k) included in the principal CNF. However, these indices can't be determined without knowledge of a specific truth value assignment to the variables p, q, and r.

[[Answer: Given that formula A contains 4 propositional variables, if it is both a tautology and a basic form, it should be denoted as either m0 (if all the variables are negated) or M15 (if no variables are negated, in the case of 4 variables). To clarify, a basic form denotes a formula that is the "simplest sum" (in the sense of disjunctive normal form) of 1 or more paired disjunctive terms. In this case, since A is both a tautology and a basic form, it implies that A is the simplest sum of paired disjunctive terms that evaluates to true for all possible assignments of the variables.

Now, recall that a paired disjunctive term is a sum of paired conjunctive terms, and a paired conjunctive term is simply a conjunction (of one type) of the propositional variables and their negations, where each variable and its negation appear exactly once. Since A is both a tautology and a basic form, it can be represented by a single paired disjunctive term, since A is the simplest sum of paired disjunctive terms.

Given that A is a tautology, when all the variables are assigned false, the paired disjunctive term representing A must evaluate to true. Under this condition, since all the variables are false, the paired conjunctive term corresponding to each variable will evaluate to true due to the presence of the negations. Therefore, each paired conjunctive term evaluates to true under the assignment of all variables as false, so the binary representation of the hexadecimal number corresponding to the paired disjunctive term should contain all 1's, which corresponds to the hexadecimal number F (or decimal 15).

Since A is a basic form, the paired disjunctive term representing A should use the minimum number of paired conjunctive terms while still evaluating to true under all possible assignments of the variables. In the case of 4 variables, it turns out that the minimum number of paired conjunctive terms needed is one, resulting in a paired disjunctive term that uses one 4-variable paired conjunctive term (representing the conjunction of all 4 variables or their negations) in its sum. Since all variables are negated in this case, the corresponding paired disjunctive term should be denoted as m0, not M15.]]

[[Answer: Given that formula A contains 4 propositional variables, if it is both a tautology and a basic form, it should be denoted as either m0 (if all the variables are negated) or M15 (if no variables are negated, in the case of 4 variables). To clarify, a basic form denotes a formula that is the "simplest sum" (in the sense of disjunctive normal form) of 1 or more paired disjunctive terms. In this case, since A is both a tautology and a basic form, it implies that A is the simplest sum of paired disjunctive terms that evaluates to true for all possible assignments of the variables.

Now, recall that a paired disjunctive term is a sum of paired conjunctive terms, and a paired conjunctive term is simply a conjunction (of one type) of the propositional variables and their negations, where each variable and its negation appear exactly once. Since A is both a tautology and a basic form, it can be represented by a single paired disjunctive term, since A is the simplest sum of paired disjunctive terms.

Given that A is a tautology, when all the variables are assigned false, the paired disjunctive term representing A must evaluate to true. Under this condition, since all the variables are false, the paired conjunctive term corresponding to each variable will evaluate to true due to the presence of the negations. Therefore, each paired conjunctive term evaluates to true under the assignment of all variables as false, so the binary representation of the hexadecimal number corresponding to the paired disjunctive term should contain all 1's, which corresponds to the hexadecimal number F (or decimal 15).

Since A is a basic form, the paired disjunctive term representing A should use the minimum number of paired conjunctive terms while still evaluating to true under all possible assignments of the variables. In the case of 4 variables, it turns out that the minimum number of paired conjunctive terms needed is one, resulting in a paired disjunctive term that uses one 4-variable paired conjunctive term (representing the conjunction of all 4 variables or their negations) in its sum. Since all variables are negated in this case, the corresponding paired disjunctive term should be denoted as m0, not M15.]]

Out of the 16 possibilities, the ones with the following conditional indices, when expressed in binary form, satisfy the even property: 0000, 0010, 0100, 0110, 1000, 1010, 1100, and 1110. However, since we are looking for a formula that is also a basic form, we are interested in the paired conjunctive terms with index 0, which is m0.

My apologies for the confusion, here is the correct answer:

For (¬p ∨ q)∧(p ∨ q) ∧ (q), the question asks to determine if the given conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment using the Resolution Algorithm. In this case, the initial S0, S1 and S2 are all empty, and S1 contains one simple disjunctive clause: {(¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), q}.

1. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
   - C1 = (¬p ∨ q) and C2 = (p ∨ q): dispel(C1, C2) = (¬p ∧ p) ∨ (¬p ∧ q) ∨ (p ∧ q), which is unsatisfiable, so we can conclude that the S has no satisfying assignment.
   - Since (¬p ∧ p) is unsatisfiable, we exit the algorithm and the output is "Implausible."

Since we were able to find an unsatisfiable clause in just one cycle, there is only one cycle in the resolution algorithm for this question.

[[Implausible; 1]]

[∅; {p∨q, p∨¬q, ¬r}; ∅]

Explanation:

1. Initialization:
   - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
   - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S. S1 = {p∨q, p∨¬q, q∨¬r, q∨r}.

2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
   - There are no clauses in S0 to resolve with any clauses in S1.

3. Resolve clauses in S1:
   - There are no pairs of clauses in S1 to resolve (since all clauses have conflicting literals).

4. Check S2:
   - S2 is empty because no clauses were resolved and no clauses were removed from S1.

5. Since S2 is empty, the algorithm has not found a contradiction, so S0, S1, and S2 are updated before the second cycle of the algorithm:
- S0 = [∅]
- S1 = {p∨q, p∨¬q, q∨¬r, q∨r}
- S2 = ∅

[["Implausible"];[5]]

Explanation:

1. Initialization:
	* S0 = {}
	* S1 = {p, p∨q, p∨¬q, q∨¬r, q∨r}
	* S2 = {}
2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
	* Resolve p with p∨q: dispel(p, p∨q) = q (since resolved literal is p, add q to S2)
	* Resolve p with p∨¬q: dispel(p, p∨¬q) = ¬q (since resolved literal is p, add ¬q to S2)
	* Resolve p∨¬q with q∨¬r: dispel(p∨¬q, q∨¬r) = ¬r (since resolved literal is q, add ¬r to S2)
	* Resolve q∨¬r with q∨r: dispel(q∨¬r, q∨r) = 0 (contradictory pair of literals, output "Implausible" and terminate the calculation)
3. Check S2: S2 contains elements, so add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, and start a new cycle.
4. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
	* Resolve q (from S2) with q∨¬r (from S1): dispel(q, q∨¬r) = ¬r (since resolved literal is q, add ¬r to S2)
	* Resolve ¬r (from S2) with q∨r (from S1): dispel(¬r, q∨r) = q (since resolved literal is ¬r, add q to S2)
	* Resolve q (from S2) with q (from S2): dispel(q, q) = 0 (contradictory pair of literals, output "Implausible" and terminate the calculation)
5. Check S2: S2 contains elements, so add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, and start a new cycle.
6. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
	* No new resolvable pairs are found, so S2 remains empty.
7. Check S2: S2 is empty, output "Plausible" and terminate the calculation.

Thus, the algorithm iterates 4 cycles before determining that the input has no satisfying assignment (i.e., is implausible).

I apologize for the confusion in my initial responses. Here is the correct answer:

[[I1, I2, O]; [- , +, -]; [+, -, +]]

In this case, we have two inputs (I1 and I2), and the negation (¬) is applied to the conjunction (∧) of these two inputs. The truth table for ¬(p∧q) is as follows:

|   p  |   q   | ¬(p∧q) |
|------|-------|--------|
|   +   |   +   |     -   |
|   +   |   -   |     -   |
|   -   |   +   |     +   |
|   -   |   -   |     +   |

Translating this into the format specified in the logic rule, the corresponding simple circuit diagram is as follows:

[[I1, I2, O]; [- , +, -]; [+, -, +]]

In this circuit, if both inputs I1 and I2 are powered (+), the output O is not powered (-). Conversely, if either of the inputs is not powered (-), the output O is powered (+). This circuit behaves as the negation of the conjunction of I1 and I2.
[[:I1, I2]; [(I1 AND I2), (I1 AND I2) OR (I1 AND I3)]; [+(I1 AND I2), (+I1 AND I2) OR (+I1 AND I3)]; [-(NOT I1), -(NOT I2)]]

response: [[O= +]] I apologize for the confusion, the correct answer is "An OR gate returns a high (or powered) output when at least one of its inputs is high. In this case, since I1 is '-' (low or unpowered) and I2 is '+', the output O should be '+'." Thank you for bringing this to my attention.

[[O-]]

To clarify, per the given rule:
- "+" represents a powered circuit (indicating a logical 1)
- "-" represents an unpowered circuit (indicating a logical 0)
- since both inputs (I1 and I2) are defined for an AND gate, we evaluate them jointly, not separately.
- when given two logical inputs for an AND gate and none are powered (i.e., both inputs are "-"), the output [[O-]] is a logical 0 because none of the input conditions are satisfied for a "1".
- When given an AND gate with only one input, we consider the "negation" operator because the second input will always be "-" by default if it's unreferenced, that results in a logical 1 (powered) if the single input is powered (i.e., "+") and a logical 0 (unpowered) if the single input is unpowered (i.e., "-").

In this specific question:
- I1 is powered "+", I2 is not powered "-"
- Since the AND operation requires both inputs to be powered for a 1, with one powered input and the other unpowered, the output will be logical 0 (unpowered) [[O-]]

[[True]]

Let's break it down:

1. The given logical expression is (p ∧ q) ∨ (¬p ∧ r).
2. "p" corresponds to I1 as "+", so p = True.
3. "q" corresponds to I2 as "-", so q = False.
4. "r" corresponds to I3 as "+", so r = True.
5. "¬p" corresponds to the negation of I1, which, since I1 = "+", means the negation results in "-".
6. Now, we can use the truth table for the logical expressions "∧" (conjunction) and "∨" (disjunction) to determine the result.

For "¬p ∧ r", if we replace p with True and r with True, the result is False (since the negation of True is False).
For (p ∧ q), if we replace p with True and q with False, the result is also False.

7. To find the final result, we use the disjunction "∨" which in this case combines two false results. Since disjunction returns True if at least one of the inputs is True, in this case, the result is True.
8. Therefore, the output of the circuit diagram is True.

Hence, the output should be: [[True]]

In the interpretation J, the formula becomes: ∃x FJ(fJ(x,x),gJ(x,x))

What we need to find are the natural numbers which satisfy this formula. To do that, we need to find where the function fJ(x,x) equals the function gJ(x,x), i.e., where x+x equals x*x.

1. fJ(0,0) = 0 + 0 = 0
2. gJ(0,0) = 0 * 0 = 0
3. 0 = 0

Since we found one natural number, 0, that satisfies the equation, we can conclude that the implementation of the formula under interpretation J is:

[[∃x FJ(fJ(x,x),gJ(x,x)) -> ∃x (x·0 + x) = (x·0)·x]]

However, it is important to note that there are no other natural numbers which satisfy the equation x+x = x*x. Therefore, the interpretation J only satisfies the formula when x=0. We can express this more formally as follows:

[[∃x FJ(fJ(x,x),gJ(x,x)) -> (∃x FJ(fJ(x,x),gJ(x,x)) ↔ x=0 )]]

Note that the "↔" symbol represents logical equivalence. Also, in this case, "(∃x FJ(fJ(x,x),gJ(x,x)) ↔ x=0)" can be read as "The formula is true if and only if x is equal to 0."

- '∃x,y' represents 'there exist x and y'

- Conclusion is the inferred statement that all instances of class S possess the property P: forall e in B, P(e).

- Premise: Observations of instances b1, b2, b3 all possessing property P (being blue), where these instances are part of class S (the B class).
- Conclusion: Based on limited observation, it is inferred that all instances e in class B possess property P.

Therefore, the answer for the conclusion symbolisation is [[forall e in B, P(e)]].

However, we can't directly calculate the exact percentage (percentage of 50 is always 100%) without more information about the class size. But since all students in the sample received an A, it means that if every student in the class had taken the test, every student would have received an A. So, theoretically, the percentage of students that would get an A would be 100%. But, in reality, as there might be more students than just the sample size, the exact percentage would still be 100%, but not all students will actually get an A.

However, within the provided format, we can't represent 100% as a percentage. So, the closest approximation would be [[100%]]. But it's important to note that this represents a theoretical maximum, not a realistic expectation given the sample size.

According to the P-Generalization rule, if `k` individuals in the sample possess a certain attribute, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess that attribute. In this case, we have `k = 4`, `n = 5`, and the attribute is an AQI below 50. So, the proportion of days in which the average AQI of the city was below 50 can be estimated as `4/5 = 0.80, or [[80%]]`.
Approximately 75% of patients ([[75%]]) may show a positive response to the new drug, based on the P-Generalization rule.

Based on the U-generalization rule provided, if all individuals (20 bird species) in the sample show good health (`n = 20`), we can infer that all individuals in the population (the entire bird species on the island) may also be healthy.

However, since we only have information about the health status of a sample of the bird species, we cannot give an exact proportion of healthy birds on the island. We can only say that "all" or 100% of the observed bird species on the sample are healthy. To estimate the proportion of healthy birds across the whole island, more data would be needed to generalize the finding.

So, while we cannot directly give an estimate of the percentage of healthy birds on the whole island using the current information, we can say that it affirms that [[100%]] of the sample (20 birds) are healthy.
Using the P-Generalization rule, if `P(Defective, 2, 50)`, then `Pr(Defective) ≈ 2/50 = 0.04`. So, the rate of defective products for the entire batch would be approximately [[4%]].

We are comparing the proportion of individuals who exercise daily in two regions, and we are inferring that these two regions may have populations with similar proportions of individuals who exercise daily.

Symbolization:

* We are comparing the proportions of individuals in each region who exercise daily, which are 90 out of 100 (90/100) in Region A and 75 out of 150 (75/150) in Region B.

In this case, Wang Meng spending a long time online (Q) is true, but it's not necessarily that he is an internet enthusiast (P). [[E]]. The reasoning displayed is an example of the Disjunctive Syllogism Fallacy (E). In Disjunctive Syllogism, we are given two statements: P or Q, and P is false. Since P is false, we assume Q must be true, but that assumption is incorrect. In this case, the rule "Du Fu is either a great poet or a person from the Tang Dynasty, and Du Fu is not a person from the Tang Dynasty" can be seen as a P is false scenario, and thus the given reasoning is a Disjunctive Syllogism Fallacy.
